t: Isaiah 23
A Prophecy Against Tyre
A*p prophecy against Tyre: Wail,*pn you ships of Tarshish! For*ld Tyre is destroyed and*ld left without house or harbor. From*ln the land of Cyprus word*ld has come to them.
Be*pn silent, you people of the island and*ld you merchants of Sidon, whom*ld the seafarers have enriched.
On*ln the great waters came*ld the grain of the Shihor; the*ln harvest of the Nile was the revenue of Tyre, and*ld she became the marketplace of the nations.
Be*pn ashamed, Sidon, and you fortress of the sea, for*ld the sea has spoken: “I*ln have neither been in labor nor given birth; I*ld have neither reared sons nor brought up daughters.”
When*ln word comes to Egypt, they*ld will be in anguish at the report from Tyre.
Cross*pn over to Tarshish; wail,*ld you people of the island.
Is*ln this your city of revelry, the*ld old, old city, whose*ln feet have taken her to*ld settle in far-off lands?
Who*ln planned this against Tyre, the*ld bestower of crowns, whose*ln merchants are princes, whose*ld traders are renowned in the earth?
The*ln Lord*s Almighty planned it, to*ld bring down her pride in all her splendor and*ld to humble all who are renowned on the earth.
Till*pn your land as they do along the Nile, Daughter*ld Tarshish, for*ld you no longer have a harbor.
The*ln Lord*s has stretched out his hand over the sea and*ld made its kingdoms tremble. He*ln has given an order concerning Phoenicia that*ld her fortresses be destroyed.
He*ln said, “No more of your reveling, Virgin*ld Daughter Sidon, now crushed! “Up,*pn cross over to Cyprus; even*ld there you will find no rest.”

Look*ln at the land of the Babylonians, this*ld people that is now of no account! The*ln Assyrians have made it a*ld place for desert creatures; they*ln raised up their siege towers, they*ld stripped its fortresses bare and*ld turned it into a ruin.
Wail,*pn you ships of Tarshish; your*ld fortress is destroyed!
At*p that time Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, the span of a king’s life. But at the end of these seventy years, it will happen to Tyre as in the song of the prostitute:
“Take*pn up a harp, walk through the city, you*ld forgotten prostitute; play*ln the harp well, sing many a song, so*ld that you will be remembered.”
At*p the end of seventy years, the Lord*s will deal with Tyre. She will return to her lucrative prostitution and will ply her trade with all the kingdoms on the face of the earth.
Yet her profit and her earnings will be set apart for the Lord;*s they will not be stored up or hoarded. Her profits will go to those who live before the Lord,*s for abundant food and fine clothes.
